title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress recognizes that bullying and harassment in schools can harm students' physical and mental health, hinder learning, and lead to negative outcomes such as high dropout rates and academic underachievement. These behaviors create a climate of fear and disrespect that impairs students' ability to participate in educational opportunities. Bullying behaviors negatively impact students' ability to learn and participate in school activities. These behaviors include physical violence, name-calling, intimidation, and cyberbullying. Schools with anti-bullying policies have increased reporting and teacher intervention in such incidents. Policies have increased reporting and teacher intervention in bullying and harassment incidents, reducing their frequency. Students are targeted based on race, color, national origin, sex, disability status, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. Some experience relational aggression or psychological bullying. Interventions to address bullying and harassment aim to create a positive and safe school climate, utilizing evidence-based discipline policies like Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) and restorative practices to prevent students from being excluded or pushed towards the juvenile justice system. According to a poll, 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying in schools. Students, parents, educators, and policymakers are calling for action to address the national crisis of bullying and harassment. SEC. 3. SAFE SCHOOLS IMPROVEMENT. This section adds a new part to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to address bullying and harassment in public schools. The purpose is to address the issue of bullying and harassment among students. It includes provisions for anti-bullying policies. The new part of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act addresses bullying, including cyberbullying, in public schools. States receiving grants must require local educational agencies to establish policies preventing severe, persistent, or pervasive conduct that limits students' participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act addresses bullying in public schools, requiring policies to prevent conduct that limits student participation or creates a hostile environment. Policies must prohibit bullying or harassment based on a student's race or color. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act mandates policies in public schools to prevent bullying or harassment based on a student's race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, or any other defining characteristics determined by the State or local educational agency. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act requires public schools to prevent bullying or harassment based on various characteristics determined by the State or local educational agency. Schools must provide annual notice of prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act mandates public schools to prevent bullying and harassment based on specified characteristics. Schools must notify about prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints, including details on who receives complaints and timelines for resolution. Data on incidents related to prohibited conduct must be collected annually. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act requires schools to collect annual data on incidents of prohibited conduct, report it publicly at the school and district levels, and ensure the confidentiality of victims and perpetrators. Positive and preventative approaches to school discipline should be encouraged to minimize student removal from instruction. Encourage positive and preventative approaches to school discipline to minimize student removal from instruction and ensure fair treatment for all students. State reports must be submitted by the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in cooperation with the State educational agency. The report should include information from local educational agencies and describe the State's plans to support efforts in addressing prohibited conduct. The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of programs to combat bullying in schools, assessing if requirements have reduced prohibited conduct and implemented effective parent involvement. The Commissioner for Education Statistics will collect data from States to determine the frequency of prohibited conduct. The Secretary will collect data from States subject to independent review to determine the frequency of prohibited conduct in schools. A biennial report will be submitted to the President and Congress with evaluation findings and data collected. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The text chunk discusses how federal and state nondiscrimination laws are not invalidated or limited by the current part, including laws such as title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The current part does not affect existing federal laws protecting freedom of speech and expression. The text introduces a new section, Part G - Safe Schools Improvement, under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Section 4706 clarifies that states and local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with this part.
